subject: Re: [junit] How do I make Unit Testing practical?

messageBody:
For the last two years we have been writing "real applications" that have
unit tests for every method. These are complex, web-based apps that
currently process billions of dollars worth of financial transactions each
week. The largest of these consists of over 500 source files, with over 200
of these being test classes. The 900+ "basic" unit tests run in just under
15 seconds, every time someone does a build. There are another 100
integration-type tests (also written in JUnit) that run in 10-12 minutes
with every checkin.

My point with all of these numbers is that it is possible--and desirable--to
do unit testing for large applications. No way would we live without our
unit tests. They have saved us many time, and enable us to make changes and
add new functionality *much* faster than we otherwise could.

The biggest thing that is required to get started is a commitment on the
part of all invovled. Just commit to yourselves and each other that you
won't write any more code that doesn't have a unit test for it. It does
take some time up front to get it all figured out. You have to learn the
basic testing patterns. You will probably have to tweak your architecture
some so that you can write less-coupled code. You have to get a feel for
when to use a mock object, when to override a method in an anonymous
subclass (Java), how to write container-based code that will run outside a
container, etc.

So it shouldn't be surprising that there is ramp-up time before you really
get good at this. Like trying to learn any new skill, it *does* initially
slow you down before it speeds you up. And yes, it's difficult while you're
still a novice. But they payoff is well worth it! When we started two
years ago, we had many of the same questions and concerns that you do. But
now we're at the point where the question of whether to write unit tests as
we develop is a non-issue. As far as we're concerned, you might as well try
to write code without a compiler--you could do it, but why would you?

The good news is that people have solved almost all of the issues you are
likely to encounter. If you ask the right questions, you can find papers &
examples of how to unit test almost every kind of code. A book you should
watch for is Dave Astel's soon-to-be-published "A Practical Guide to
Test-Driven Development".

Jeff Nielsen
Digital Focus
www.digitalfocus.com

From: "swpalmer2001" <scott.palmer@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, April 01, 2003 3:07 PM
Subject: [junit] How do I make Unit Testing practical?


> First off I better say up front that this is not meant as a troll, or
> to start some sort of flame war about unit testing.... I'm really
> looking for simple insight from people who have been where I am now,
> links to articles on the web and so forth....
>
> I like, the rest off you, have heard great things about unit testing.
> I believe a lot of it. I want to start writing unit tests for my
> code and in general improve my development practices. So I downloaded
> JUnit, and read through some articles and examples.
>
> They are all too trivial.
>
> I am struggling as to how I can write unit tests for "real code".
> Most of the examples I see are testing objects that are VERY general
> (lists, or other simple container classes, a calculator, etc..).
> But my "real classes" are written for my "real application" and as
> such there is an entire environment that is created as they work
> together. Testing the classes in isolation seems next to impossible.
>
> Some people will be quick to jump in and say that this must be a
> fundamental problem with my design.. my classes shouldn't be so
> dependent on each other, or something similar. In some (trivial)
> cases it is possible to write stand alone classes, and they are
> fairly easy to test in isolation. But a complex application needs
> all sorts of classes that bind trivial bits together... and these
> classes must rely on the very classes that they are causing to work
> together.
>
> I find that it is these classes that are difficult to
> compartmentalize where most of my bugs tend to show up anyway, but of
> course not always. How do you unit test such beasts?
>
> So far in all my attempts to get started at this I find that the test
> code itself becomes very complex - not as complex as my application,
> but enough that the time I would end up writing and debugging the
> test seems completely unreasonable. I would love to have the
> finished tests, but I simply can't see how I could justify writing
> them, as it would more than double my design and coding development
> time.
>
> In the end I would almost end up with an "automated user", and of
> course that is a tad extreme and prone to it's own sorts of errors
> and assumptions.
>
> I've told co-workers about what I have read about unit testing,
> testing frameworks etc. None of my co-workers do unit tests, and ll
> of them have the same attitude. Unit testing is too
> complex/difficult to use when making real complete programs.
>
> So I'm asking... Who else has been down this path? How do I get past
> this point? Am I making sense or have I just gotten something
> completely wrong? Or is this unit testing just a passing fad that is
> really nothing more than a bunch of hype?
>
